article.title: Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771
article.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}}
{{Infobox Aircraft occurrence
| name             = Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771
| occurrence_type  = Accident
| image            = Afriqiyah Airways Airbus A330.jpg
| image_size       = 250
| alt              = 
| caption          =The [[Airbus A330|Airbus A330-202]], 5A-ONG, involved in the accident
| date             = 12 May 2010
| type             = [[Controlled flight into terrain]] caused by [[spatial disorientation]], [[pilot error]], and lack of cockpit collaboration 
| site             = On approach to runway 09 at [[Tripoli International Airport]] in Tripoli, Libya
| coordinates      = {{Coord|32|39|41|N|13|7|9|E|type:event|display=inline,title}}
| aircraft_type    = [[Airbus A330|Airbus A330-202]] 
| operator         = [[Afriqiyah Airways]]
| tail_number      = 5A-ONG
| origin           = [[OR Tambo International Airport]], [[Johannesburg]], South Africa
| stopover         =
| stopover0        =
| stopover1        =
| stopover2        =
| stopover3        =
| plane1_laststopover    =
| destination      = [[Tripoli International Airport]], [[Tripoli]], Libya
| passengers       = 93
| crew             = 11
| injuries         = 1
| fatalities       = 103
| survivors        = 1 (2 initially)
}}
'''Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771''' was a scheduled international [[Afriqiyah Airways]] passenger flight that crashed on 12 May 2010 at about 06:01 [[UTC+2|local time]] (04:01 [[coordinated universal time|UTC]]) on approach to [[Tripoli International Airport]].<ref name=Afriqiyah>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriqiyah.aero/news/7-afriqiyah-flight-771-crash.html |title=Afriqiyah Flight 771 crash |publisher=Afriqiyah Airways |accessdate=12 May 2010 |date=12 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515121135/http://www.afriqiyah.aero/news/7-afriqiyah-flight-771-crash.html |archivedate=15 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} </ref><ref name=BBC8676758>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8676758.stm|title=Plane crash in Libya 'kills more than 100 on board' |publisher=BBC News|accessdate=12 May 2010|date=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100513035200/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8676758.stm| archivedate= 13 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Of the 104 passengers and crew on board, the [[List of sole survivors of airline accidents or incidents|sole survivor]] was a 9-year-old Dutch boy named Ruben van Assouw.<ref name=MSNBC>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/37100560/ns/world_news-africa/|title=Libya plane crash 'kills all 104 on board' |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |accessdate=12 May 2010|date=12 May 2010}}</ref><ref name=NOS>{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/156833-ruim-honderd-doden-bij-vliegramp-in-tripoli.html|title=Mogelijk Nederlanders aan boord crash Tripoli|publisher=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]|language=Dutch|date=12 May 2010|accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515112613/http://nos.nl/artikel/156833-ruim-honderd-doden-bij-vliegramp-in-tripoli.html| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=Telegraaf>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/6705037/__Veel_doden_bij_vliegtuigcrash__.html?p=1,1 |title=61 Nederlanders dood bij crash Tripoli |work=[[De Telegraaf]] |language=Dutch |accessdate=12 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515120325/http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/6705037/__Veel_doden_bij_vliegtuigcrash__.html?p=1%2C1 |archivedate=15 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=BrabantsDagblad>{{cite web|url=http://bd.nl/nieuws/tilburg-stad/ruben-wordt-uitstekend-verzorgd-1.33431 |title=Overlevende vliegramp is Tilburgs jongetje |work=[[Brabants Dagblad]] |language=Dutch |accessdate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809101823/http://bd.nl/nieuws/tilburg-stad/ruben-wordt-uitstekend-verzorgd-1.33431 |archivedate=9 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The crash of Flight 771 was the third hull-loss of an Airbus A330 involving fatalities, happening eleven months after the second one came with the crash of [[Air France Flight 447]].

==Aircraft==
The aircraft was an [[Airbus A330|Airbus A330-200]], registration 5A-ONG, manufactured in 2009, manufacturer's serial number (MSN) 1024. It was delivered in September 2009 and at the time of the accident it had approximately 1,600 hours total flying time and about 420 take-off and landing cycles. The aircraft was powered by two [[General Electric CF6|General Electric CF6-80E1]] engines.<ref name=Airbus>{{cite web|url=http://www.airbus.com/crisis/index.html |title=Afriqiyah Airways flight 8U771 accident in Tripoli, Libya (issue 2) |publisher=[[EADS]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090919044313/http://www.airbus.com/crisis/index.html |archivedate=19 September 2009 }}</ref><ref name=FG>{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/05/12/341870/afriqiyah-identifies-crashed-a330-200.html |title=Afriqiyah identifies crashed A330-200  |publisher=[[Flight Global]] |first=David |last=Kaminski-Morrow |accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515113032/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/05/12/341870/afriqiyah-identifies-crashed-a330-200.html| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> It was configured for a capacity of 253 passengers.<ref name=ASN120510>{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20100512-0 |title=Accident description |publisher=''[[Aviation Safety Network]]''| accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515031525/http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=20100512-0| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=NYT>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/13/world/middleeast/13libya.html |title=Jet With 104 Aboard Crashes in Libya |date=12 May 2010 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 | first=Nicola | last=Clark| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100512101224/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/13/world/middleeast/13libya.html| archivedate= 12 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> This particular flight carried 93 passengers and 11 crew. Most of the passengers were Dutch citizens returning from holiday in South Africa.<ref name=BBC8676758/><ref name=Telegraaf/> An airport official stated that 13 Libyans, both passengers and crew, as well 70 Dutch nationals had lost their lives in the crash.<ref name="reuters">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE64B16V20100512?feedType=RSS&feedName=topNews|title=Libya plane crash kills 103, Dutch child survives|date=12 May 2010|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=BBC8676898>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8676898.stm | title = Libya plane crash – 'at least one Briton on board' | publisher = BBC News| accessdate=12 May 2010|date=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100513035202/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8676898.stm| archivedate= 13 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>

==Flight==
[[File:Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The route of Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771]]
The flight originated at [[OR Tambo International Airport]], serving [[Johannesburg]], South Africa. Its destination was [[Tripoli International Airport]], Libya.<ref name=BBC8676758/> During the final approach and up to the moment of the accident the pilot had not reported any problems to the control tower.<ref name="BBC boy"/> The aircraft crashed about {{convert|1200|m|yd}} short of Runway 09, outside the airport perimeter.<ref>Final report, synopsis, p.9</ref><ref name=Jacdec>{{cite web|url=http://www.jacdec.de/news/news.htm |title=Recent accidents / incidents worldwide |publisher=[[JACDEC]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227035307/http://www.jacdec.de/news/news.htm |archivedate=27 February 2010 }}</ref> The aircraft was destroyed by the impact and post-crash fire.<ref>Final report, section 1.3, p.11</ref><ref name="aljazeera">{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/05/2010512731621627.html|title= Scores dead in Libya plane crash |date=12 May 2010|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100513034307/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/05/2010512731621627.html| archivedate= 13 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[METAR]] in force at the time of the crash was HLLT 120350Z VRB01KT 6000 NSC 19/17 Q1008.<ref name=AH42b63b20>{{cite web|url=http://avherald.com/h?article=42b63b20&opt=0 |title=Crash: Afriqiyah A332 at Tripoli on 12 May 2010 |first=Simon |last=Hradecky |publisher=''[[Aviation Herald]]'' |accessdate=17 August 2010}}</ref><sup>{{anchor|ref_A}}[[#endnote A|[A]]]</sup> The main runway of the airport is {{convert|3600|m|ft}} long.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-ap-ml-libya-plane-crash,0,3660097.story |title=Libyan jet carrying 104 crashes on approach to Tripoli; Dutch boy is sole known survivor |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=12 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515032731/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-ap-ml-libya-plane-crash%2C0%2C3660097.story |archivedate=15 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Libyan Transport Minister Mohammed Ali Zidan ruled out terrorism as a cause.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Plane-Crash-At-Libya-Tripoli-Airport-Passengers-Killed-In-Landing-Accident/Article/201005215630352?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_3&lid=ARTICLE_15630352_Plane_Crash_At_Libya_Tripoli_Airport%3A_Passengers_Killed_In_Landing_Accident |title=Terrorism Ruled Out in Tripoli Plane Crash |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=[[Sky News]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515035635/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Plane-Crash-At-Libya-Tripoli-Airport-Passengers-Killed-In-Landing-Accident/Article/201005215630352?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_3&lid=ARTICLE_15630352_Plane_Crash_At_Libya_Tripoli_Airport%3A_Passengers_Killed_In_Landing_Accident |archivedate=15 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> During the incident, the aircraft damaged a house on the ground. The homeowner, his wife, and their five children escaped unharmed. The house and a nearby mosque are scheduled to be demolished as part of the airport expansion plans.<ref>Nierop, Leonie: "[http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2544745.ece/Nog_zeven_wonderen_in_Tripoli Nóg zeven wonderen in Tripoli]." NRC Handelsblad, 15 May 2010. Retrieved on 16 May 2010.</ref> The first body of a non-Libyan passenger was repatriated to [[Kingdom of the Netherlands|the Netherlands]] on 27 May 2010.<ref name="Flightindex"/> On 21 June 2010 the Libyan authorities began clearing the accident site of Afriqiyah 771.<ref name="Flightindex">"[https://web.archive.org/web/20100518144526/http://www.afriqiyah.aero/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70 Flight Afriqiyah Airways 771 Johannesburg – Tripoli]." Afriqiyah Airways.</ref>

The accident is the second deadliest involving an [[Airbus A330]] (after [[Air France Flight 447]]), and the second deadliest accident to have happened in Libya.<ref name=ASN120510/> It was the first hull-loss accident for Afriqiyah Airways.<ref name=Jacdec/>

==Investigation==
The [[Libyan Civil Aviation Authority]] (LYCAA<!--LYCAA, NOT LCAA-->) opened an investigation into the accident.<ref name=Tripoli>{{cite web|url=http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=4432 |title=Plane Crushes at Tripoli Airport, 104 Passengers on Board, 9-year-Old Boy Survives |publisher=[[Tripoli Post]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516072147/http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=4432 |archivedate=16 May 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[Airbus]] stated that it would provide full technical assistance to the authorities investigating the crash,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100512-705254.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLEHeadlinesMideast|title=Airbus To Provide Technical Help in Libya Crash Investigation |date=12 May 2010|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515035510/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100512-705254.html?mod=WSJ_World_MIDDLEHeadlinesMideast| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} {{Registration required}}</ref> and would do so via the French [[Bureau d'Enquêtes et d'Analyses pour la Sécurité de l'Aviation Civile]] (BEA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://classic.eads.net/1024/en/pressdb/pressdb/20100512_airbus_libya_accident.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707192323/http://classic.eads.net/1024/en/pressdb/pressdb/20100512_airbus_libya_accident.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 July 2012 |title=Afriqiyah Airways aircraft accident in Libya |publisher=[[EADS]] |date=12 May 2010 |accessdate=16 May 2010}}</ref> The [[South African Civil Aviation Authority]] sent a team to assist with the investigation.<ref name="businessday">{{cite news|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/Content.aspx?id=108729|title=CAA team to travel to Libya to assist in crash investigation|date=12 May 2010|publisher=Business Day|accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> The BEA assisted in the investigation with an initial team of two investigators, accompanied by five advisors from Airbus.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bea.aero/en/enquetes/flight.8u.771/pressrelease12may2010.php |title=Press release, 12 May 2010 |date=12 May 2010 |publisher=[[Bureau d'Enquêtes et d'Analyses pour la Sécurité de l'Aviation Civile]] |accessdate=12 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6G6loNiGb?url=http://www.bea.aero/en/enquetes/flight.8u.771/pressrelease12may2010.php |archivedate=24 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> The [[Dutch Safety Board]] (Onderzoeksraad voor de Veiligheid "Research Council for Safety") sent an observer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.trouw.nl/nieuws/nederland/article3066713.ece/Onderzoeksraad_stuurt_waarnemer_naar_Tripoli.html|title=Onderzoeksraad stuurt waarnemer naar Tripoli, 12 May 2010|date=12 May 2010|publisher=[[Trouw]]|language=Dutch|accessdate=16 May 2010}}{{dead link|date=July 2011}}</ref> The [[flight recorder]]s were recovered and sent to Paris for analysis soon after the incident.<ref name="BBC boy">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8684060.stm |title=Dutch boy who survived Libya crash flies home  |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=16 May 2010|date=15 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100517053015/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8684060.stm| archivedate= 17 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=BBC8679254>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8679254.stm |title=Investigation begins into cause of Tripoli air crash |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=13 May 2010 | date=13 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100819190029/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8679254.stm| archivedate=19 August 2010| deadurl= no}}</ref>

Authorities reviewed the recordings made by the [[Flight Data Recorder]]<ref name=CNNSources>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/15/libyan.crash.survivor/index.html?hpt=T2 |title=Sources: Pilot in Libyan crash hampered by low visibility |publisher=CNN |accessdate=16 May 2010 | date=16 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100519121927/http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/15/libyan.crash.survivor/index.html?hpt=T2| archivedate= 19 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> In August 2010, it was reported that preliminary investigations were complete. There was no evidence of any technical problems nor was there any fuel shortage. No technical or medical problems had been reported by the crew and they had not requested any assistance.<ref name=AH42b63b20/> Due to the [[2011 Libyan civil war]], the investigation was being hampered, with the [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] unable to get any response from the LYCAA. The data from the Cockpit Voice Recorder and Flight Data Recorder had been extracted, and the results given to the LYCAA.

On 28 February 2013, the [[Libyan Civil Aviation Authority]] announced that they had determined that the cause of the crash was pilot error. [[Crew resource management]] lacked/was insufficient, [[Sensory illusions in aviation|sensory illusions]] and the first officer inputs to the aircraft [[Side-stick|side stick]] were a contributing factor in the crash. Also fatigue could have played a role in the accident.

The final report stated that the accident resulted from the pilots’ lack of a common action plan during the approach, the final approach being continued below the Minimum Decision Altitude without ground visual reference being acquired, the inappropriate application of flight control inputs during the go-around and after the activation of the Terrain Awareness and Warning System, and the flight crew’s lack of monitoring and controlling of the flight path.<ref name=Final>{{cite web |url=https://aviation-safety.net/investigation/reports/771/FINAL_5A-ONG-1.pdf |title=Final Report of AFRIQIYAH AIRWAYS Aircraft Airbus A320-232, 5A-ONG Crash Occurred at Tripoli (LIBYA) on 12/05/2010 |publisher=Libyan Civil Aviation Authority |date=February 2013 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref>

=== Accident description ===
The flight crew did not acquire any visual ground references before the approach was started. The aircraft started its final descent for landing too early. The aircraft had descended to 280 feet above ground when the [[terrain awareness and warning system]] sounded in the cockpit. The captain ordered a [[go-around]] and the [[autopilot]] was turned off. The first officer put the nose of the aircraft up for 4 seconds and the thrust levers were set to go-around power. The aircraft pitched up to 12.3° nose up and the flight crew raised the landing gear and flaps. Shortly thereafter the co-pilot started making nose down inputs which caused the aircraft to pitch-attitude to reduce to 3.5° nose down. (The co-pilot could have been focused on the aircraft's speed, rather than its altitude.) The go-around pitch attitude was not maintained and the instructions from the flight director were not followed. (The report says that fatigue could have played a role in causing the first officer to focus solely on the airspeed.) The captain and the first officer were making inputs to the aircraft's side stick at the same time (although the dual inputs were not sufficient to trigger a dual-input warning). This action appears to be intended to provide assistance by the captain to fly the aircraft. This action led to confusion on who was flying the aircraft. The [[ground proximity warning system]] sounded as the aircraft lost more height and the co-pilot responded with a sharp nose-down input. Then the captain took control of the aircraft without warning, via the side stick priority button and maintained the nose-down input, while the first officer was simultaneously pulling back on his own side stick. Two seconds before impact with the ground the aircraft was at 180 feet. The captain was also pulling his side stick fully back, suggesting both pilots were aware of the aircraft's impending collision with the ground. However, the captain then pushed his control stick forward, causing the aircraft to descend again. Two seconds later, the aircraft crashed into the ground at high speed and exploded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/illusion-and-dual-control-led-to-afriqiyah-a330-crash-382873/|title=Illusion and dual control led to Afriqiyah A330 crash |work=[[Flightglobal]]|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caa.ly/finalReport/FINAL_5A-ONG-4.pdf|title=Final Report of AFRIQIYAH Airways Aircraft Airbus A330-202, 5A-ONG Crash Occurred at Tripoli (LIBYA) on 12/05/2010|work=[[Libyan Civil Aviation Authority]]|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref>

==Reactions==
Afriqiyah Airways issued a statement saying that relatives of the victims who wished to visit Libya would be transported and accommodated at Afriqiyah's expense. The Libyan authorities relaxed certain passport restrictions and guaranteed the granting of visas.<ref name="Afriqiyahrel6">"[https://web.archive.org/web/20100824055357/http://www.afriqiyah.aero/about-us/flight-8u771.html Flight Afriqiyah Airways 771 Johannesburg – Tripoli]" (). Afriqiyah Airways. Retrieved on 29 August 2010.</ref> By 15 May 2010 the airline opened the Family Assistance Centre in a hotel in [[Tripoli]] to care for family members and relatives of crash victims who were visiting Libya. The executive team of Afriqiyah, including the CEO and the chairperson of the board, met family members at the hotel. Some family members wanted to visit the crash site; they travelled to the site and placed flowers there.<ref name="Afriqiyahrel6"/> The airline permanently retired the flight number 771 and it has been re-designated to 788 for Tripoli to Johannesburg and 789 for the return flight.<ref name="Flightindex"/>

Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]] expressed her shock at hearing the news.<ref name=NRC>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrc.nl/binnenland/article2542766.ece/61_Nederlanders_dood_bij_vliegtuigcrash_Libie|title=61 Nederlanders dood bij vliegtuigcrash Libië|publisher=[[NRC Handelsblad]]|language=Dutch|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> The [[President of South Africa]], [[Jacob Zuma]], also offered his condolences.<ref name=BBC8676758/>

==Passengers and crew==
<!--**********PLEASE only use the airline's list – Dual nationalities are noted below!*******-->
The passengers aboard Flight 771 were of various nationalities. All of the eleven crew members were Libyans. One passenger held dual citizenship. The following list reflects the airline's passenger nationality count of the victims.<ref name="Afriqiyahrel6"/> The airline released the manifest on the morning of 15 May 2010; the airline sent the list to several related embassies.<ref name="Afriqiyahrel6"/>

{| class="wikitable"
|-

! rowspan="2" style="width:70px;"|Total

| 92

| 1

|}
<small>* one South African passport holder, [[Bree O'Mara]], had dual South African and Irish citizenships.<ref name=rte>{{cite web | url = http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0512/libya.html | title = 103 dead in Libyan plane crash | publisher=[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs]]| accessdate=13 May 2010| date=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515035220/http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0512/libya.html| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=BSA>{{cite web|url=http://news.book.co.za/blog/2010/05/13/irish-south-african-author-bree-omara-killed-in-libya-plane-crash/ |title=Irish-South African Author Bree O'Mara Killed in Libya Plane Crash |publisher=BOOK South Africa |accessdate=13 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100527043819/http://news.book.co.za/blog/2010/05/13/irish-south-african-author-bree-omara-killed-in-libya-plane-crash/ |archivedate=27 May 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref></small>

The sole survivor was 9-year-old Ruben van Assouw (though some reports stated that he was either 8 or 10), a resident of the Dutch city of [[Tilburg]],<ref name="BrabantsDagblad"/><ref name="reuters" /><ref name=cnn>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/12/libya.planecrash/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Child survives as 100 feared dead in Libya plane crash|date=12 May 2010|publisher=CNN|accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515062251/http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/12/libya.planecrash/index.html?hpt=T1| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>Nield, Barry. "[http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/13/libya.planecrash.survivors/index.html?hpt=C1 Fate or fluke? Air crash sole survivors]." CNN. 13 May 2010. Retrieved on 13 May 2010.</ref> who was returning from a safari with his parents and brother.<ref name="BrabantsDagblad"/><ref>"[http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=6&art_id=98223&sid=28241408&con_type=1&d_str=20100514&fc=7 `Miracle' Dutch boy confused but stable] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629171603/http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=6&art_id=98223&sid=28241408&con_type=1&d_str=20100514&fc=7 |date=29 June 2011 }}." ''[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]]''. Friday 14 May 2010. Retrieved on 13 May 2010.</ref> Van Assouw was taken to Sabia'a Hospital, {{convert|30|km|mi}} south-east of Tripoli and later transferred to Al-Khadhra Hospital, Tripoli,<ref name=Tripoli/> to undergo surgery for multiple fractures in both legs.<ref>El-Tablawy, Tarek. "[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jYrDcPk-L1tWUbIHWbZiW-7oCIkgD9FM72OG0 A safari ends in tragedy for lone crash survivor]." ''[[Associated Press]]'' at ''[[Google News]]''. 14 May 2010. Retrieved on 14 May 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516024311/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jYrDcPk-L1tWUbIHWbZiW-7oCIkgD9FM72OG0 |date=16 May 2010 }}</ref> [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands)|Dutch Foreign Ministry]] spokesman Ad Meijer said the child has no life-threatening injuries.<ref name=BBC8676758/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/12/libya.planecrash/index.html |title = Child is lone survivor in Libya plane crash| publisher = CNN| accessdate=13 May 2010|date=13 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100513031731/http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/africa/05/12/libya.planecrash/index.html| archivedate= 13 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]] and Captain Sabri Shadi, the head of Afriqiyah Airways, visited Van Assouw while he was hospitalised in Libya.<ref name="Afriqiyahrel6"/> On 15 May, he was transferred by air ambulance to [[Eindhoven Airport|Eindhoven]] in the Netherlands.<ref name="afriqiyah">{{cite news|url=http://www.afriqiyah.aero/news/73-afriqiyah-flight-771-accident-release-8.html |title=Afriqiyah Flight 771 accident release 8 21:00 UTC |date=15 May 2010 |publisher=''[[Afrigiyah Flight]]'' |accessdate=15 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100519124729/http://www.afriqiyah.aero/news/73-afriqiyah-flight-771-accident-release-8.html |archivedate=19 May 2010 |dead-url=yes }}</ref> Van Assouw was accompanied on the flight by his aunt and uncle.<ref name=BBC8684060>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8684060.stm |title=Dutch boy who survived Libya crash flies home |publisher=BBC News Online| date=15 May 2010 |accessdate=16 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100518132917/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8684060.stm| archivedate= 18 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>

Of the passengers, 42 were to continue to [[Düsseldorf]], 32 to [[Brussels]], seven to London, and one to Paris. Eleven of the passengers had Libya as their final destination.<ref name="afriqiyah"/> Of the 71<!--the "70" listed is those dead--> passengers identified as Dutch by the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands)|Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs]], 38 were travelling with the Stip [[travel agency]], 24 were travelling with the Kras travel agency, and 9, including the survivor, had their tickets booked independently.<!--The count differs from the airline's count of Dutch people--><ref>"[http://www.minbuza.nl/en/The_Ministry/Airplane_crash_in_Tripoli#internelink8 70 Dutch people killed in air crash]." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Netherlands)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands]]. Retrieved on 14 May 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823141111/http://www.minbuza.nl/en/The_Ministry/Airplane_crash_in_Tripoli#internelink8 |date=23 August 2010 }}</ref><ref>Mu, Xuequan. "[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/13/c_13293364.htm Families of Dutch crash victims arrive in Libya: agency]." ''[[Xinhua]]''. 13 May 2010. Retrieved on 14 May 2010.</ref>

Among the victims were Frans Dreyer, brother of South African [[Parliament of South Africa|Member of Parliament]] [[Anchen Dreyer]].<ref name=Beeld>{{cite web|url=http://www.beeld.com/Suid-Afrika/Nuus/Anchen-Dreyer-se-broer-op-doodsvlug-20100512 |title=Anchen Dreyer se broer op doodsvlug |publisher=[[Beeld]] |language=Afrikaans |accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515041616/http://www.beeld.com/Suid-Afrika/Nuus/Anchen-Dreyer-se-broer-op-doodsvlug-20100512| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name=Telegraaf2>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/6708547/__62_Nederlanders_aan_boord__.html |title=Afriqiyah: 62 Nederlanders aan boord |work=De Telegraaf |language=Dutch |accessdate=12 May 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100515120038/http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/6708547/__62_Nederlanders_aan_boord__.html| archivedate= 15 May 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> and his friend and colleague, Anton Matthee.  On the evening of 12 May 2010, the Irish [[Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Ireland)|Department of Foreign Affairs]] confirmed that one of its passport holders was on the plane, novelist [[Bree O'Mara]].<ref name="rte"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article7125194.ece | title = Irish author Bree O'Mara named as victim in Libyan air crash | work=[[The Times]]| accessdate=13 May 2010| date=13 May 2010 | location=London | first1=Laura | last1=Pitel | first2=Charles | last2=Bremner}}</ref> One of the Dutch victims was [[Joëlle van Noppen]], singer in the former Dutch [[girl group]] [[WOW! (band)|WOW!]].<ref name=wow>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtl.nl/(/actueel/rtlboulevard/nieuws/articleview/)/components/actueel/rtlboulevard/2010/05_mei/entertainment/ex_zangeres_wow_omgekomen.xml|title=Ex-zangeres 'WOW!' omgekomen|publisher=[[RTL Boulevard]]|language=Dutch|accessdate=14 May 2010|date=13 May 2010}}</ref>

The flight deck members were identified as Captain Yousef Bashir Al-Saadi ({{lang-ar|يوسف بشير الساعدي}}), Co-pilot Tareq Mousa Abu Al-Chaouachi ({{lang-ar|طارق موسي أبو الشواشي}}), and Co-pilot Nazim Al-Mabruk Al-Tarhuni ({{lang-ar|ناظم المبروك الترهوني}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afriqiyah.aero/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=69 |title=نعي (Obituary) |publisher=Afriqiyah Airways |accessdate=13 May 2010 |language=ar |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100517050938/http://www.afriqiyah.aero/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=69 |archivedate=17 May 2010 }}</ref>

==See also==
{{Portal|Libya|Netherlands|Aviation|Disasters|2010s}}
*[[Air France Flight 447]] – another disaster involving an Airbus A330, which occurred just less than a year before this crash took place.
*[[Airbus Industrie Flight 129]] – first fatal accident involving an A330, 7 crew members died while the aircraft stalled and crashed near Toulouse.
*[[Gulf Air Flight 072]] – crew suffered [[Sensory illusions in aviation#Vestibular/somatogravic illusions|somatogravic illusion]] during [[go-around]]
*[[Libyan Arab Airlines Flight 1103]] – the deadliest accident in Libya at the time Flight 771 crashed.
*[[List of sole survivors of airline accidents or incidents]]
